* [[Brussels Airport]] * [[Chennai International Airport]] * [[Indira Gandhi International Airport]] (Delhi) * [[Netaji Subhash Chandra Bose International Airport]] (Kolkata)
|focus_cities =
*[[Bengaluru International Airport]] (Bangalore) *[[Cochin International Airport]] (Kochi) *[[Trivandrum International Airport]](Trivandrum) *[[Dabolim Airport]] (Vasco da Gama Goa) *[[Rajiv Gandhi International Airport]] (Hyderabad) * [[Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel International Airport]] (Ahmedabad)
| lounge = Jet Lounge | alliance = | subsidiaries =[[JetLite]] | website = [http://www.jetairways.com/ www.jetairways.com] }} '''Jet Airways''' is a major [[India]]n [[airline]] based in [[Mumbai]], [[Maharashtra]]. It is India's largest airline and the market leader in the domestic sector. It operates over 400 flights daily to 76 destinations worldwide. Its main hub is [[Chhatrapati Shivaji International Airport]], with secondary hubs at [[Indira Gandhi International Airport|Delhi]], [[Chennai International Airport|Chennai]], Ahmedabad, Bengaluru and [[Netaji Subhash Chandra Bose International Airport|Kolkata]]. It has an international hub at [[Brussels Airport]], [[Belgium]]. Jet Airways is owned by [[Naresh Goyal]]. {{TOC limit|limit=3}} ==History== ===Early years=== Jet Airways was incorporated as an air taxi operator on 1 April 1992. It started commercial operations on 5 May 1993 with a fleet of four leased [[Boeing 737 Classic|Boeing 737-300]] aircraft. In January 1994 a change in the law enabled Jet Airways to apply for scheduled airline status, which was granted on 4 January 1995. It began international operations from [[Chennai]] to [[Colombo]] in March 2004. The company is listed on the [[Bombay Stock Exchange]], but 80% of its stock is controlled by Naresh Goyal (through his ownership of Jetâs parent company, Tailwinds). It has 10,017 employees (as at March 2007).[http://www.jetairways.com/Cultures/en-US/India/Investor+Relations/Overview/ Jet Airways India | Know investment options, shareholding structure, listings & stock codes]{{dead link|date=August 2010}} [[Naresh Goyal]] â who already owned Jetair (Private) Limited, which provided sales and marketing for foreign airlines in India â set up Jet Airways as a full-service scheduled airline to compete against state-owned [[Indian Airlines]]. Indian Airlines had enjoyed a monopoly in the domestic market between 1953, when all major Indian air transport providers were nationalised under the Air Corporations Act (1953), and January 1994, when the Air Corporations Act was repealed, following which Jet Airways received scheduled airline status. ===Air Sahara buyout=== In January 2006 Jet Airways announced that it would buy [[Air Sahara]] for [[US$]]500 million in an all-cash deal, making it the biggest takeover in Indian aviation history. It would have resulted in the country's largest airline{{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/4626810.stm | title = Indian airline Jet Airways is to buy rival carrier Air Sahara in a deal worth $500 m (Â£284 m). |date=2006-01-19 | publisher = BBC News}} but the deal fell through in June 2006. On 12 April 2007 Jet Airways agreed to buy out Air Sahara for INR14.5 billion (US$340 million). Air Sahara was renamed JetLite, and was marketed between a low-cost carrier and a full service airline. In August 2008 Jet Airways announced its plans to completely integrate JetLite into Jet Airways.{{cite web|author=25 Aug, 2008, 02.08AM IST, Mithun Roy,ET Bureau |url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/News_by_Industry/JetLite_may_merge_with_Jet_Airways/articleshow/3400790.cms |title=JetLite may merge with Jet Airways this year |publisher=Economictimes.indiatimes.com |date=2008-08-25 |accessdate=2010-08-30}} ===Present=== In October 2008 Jet Airways laid off 1,900 of its employees, resulting in the largest lay-off in the history of Indian aviation.{{cite web|author=Manju V, TNN, Oct 15, 2008, 09.00am IST |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/Jet_Airways_lays_off_850_flight_attendants/articleshow/3596360.cms |title=Jet Air lays off 850 flight attendants |publisher=Timesofindia.indiatimes.com |date=2008-10-15 |accessdate=2010-08-30}} However the employees were later asked to return to work; Civil Aviation Minister [[Praful Patel]] said that the management reviewed its decision after he analysed the decision with them.{{cite web|author=17 Oct, 2008, 11.36AM IST,TNN |url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/Praful_takes_credit_for_reversal_of_Jet_layoffs/articleshow/3607311.cms |title=Praful takes credit for reversal of Jet layoffs |publisher=Economictimes.indiatimes.com |date=2008-10-17 |accessdate=2010-08-30}}{{cite web|url=http://www.business-standard.com/india/storypage.php?tp=on&autono=48132 |title=Business-standard Jet Airways article |publisher=Business-standard.com |date= |accessdate=2010-08-30}} In October 2008 Jet Airways and rival [[Kingfisher Airlines]] announced an alliance which primarily includes an agreement on code-sharing on both domestic and international flights, joint fuel management to reduce expenses, common ground handling, joint utilisation of crew and sharing of similar frequent flier programmes.[http://www.jetairways.com/Cultures/en-US/Kuwait/About+Us/Press+Room/Press+Releases/9W_IT.htm Jet and Kingfisher form Alliance]{{dead link|date=August 2010}} On 8 May 2009 Jet Airways launched its low-cost brand, Jet Konnect. The decision to launch a new brand instead of expanding the JetLite network was taken after considering the regulatory delays involved in transferring aircraft from Jet Airways to JetLite, as the two have different operator codes. The brand was launched on sectors that had 50% or less load factor with the aim of increasing it to 70% and above. Jet officials said that the brand would cease to exist once the demand for the regular Jet Airways increases.{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/2009/05/08/stories/2009050851921500.htm|title=Jet Airwaysâ low-fare service Konnect takes off today|publisher=The Hindu Business Line|accessdate=}}{{dead link|date=June 2011}} According to a PTI report, for the third quarter of 2010, Jet Airways (Jet+JetLite) had a market share of 26.9%{{cite web|author=PTI, Oct 19, 2010 |url=http://business.rediff.com/report/2010/oct/19/lean-period-air-traffic-same-domestic-traffic-up.htm |title=Lean period air traffic same, domestic traffic up |publisher=Rediff.com |date=2010-10-19 |accessdate=2010-10-19}} in terms of passengers carried, thus making it a market leader in India, followed by [[Kingfisher Airlines]] with 19.9% . ====Effects of recession==== The recession forced Jet Airways to discontinue the following routes: [[Ahmedabad]]â[[London]], [[Amritsar]]â[[London]], [[Bangalore]]â[[Brussels]] and [[Mumbai]]â[[Shanghai]]â[[San Francisco]]. It also had to put an indefinite delay on its expansion plans. Jet Airways was forced to lease out seven of its ten [[Boeing 777#777-300ER|Boeing 777-300ER]]s to survive the financial crunch. Due to the recession all flights to [[North America]] were operated on an [[Airbus A330#A330-200|Airbus A330-200]] replacing the [[Boeing 777#777-300ER|Boeing 777-300ER]]s. It also had to sell a brand-new, yet-to-be-delivered Boeing 777-300ER in 2009 and had to defer all new aircraft deliveries by at least two years. The airline plans to restore the [[Mumbai]]-[[Shanghai]] route by the end of 2011.[http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-12-14/jet-air-to-resume-india-china-service-amid-very-good-growth-.html Jet Air Will Resume India-China Service Amid Good Growth, Mahadevan Says - Bloomberg] ==Corporate affairs and identity== ===Head office=== Jet Airways's head office is located in the Siroya Centre in [[Andheri]], [[Mumbai]]."[http://www.jetairways.com/EN/US/ContactUs/ContactUsRegisteredOffice.aspx Contact Us]." Jet Airways. Retrieved on 19 September 2011. "Jet Airways (India) Ltd. Siroya Centre, Sahar Airport Road, Andheri (East), Mumbai, Maharashtra 400099" Jet Airways's head office was previously located in the S.M. Centre, a rented, unmarked six storey building in Andheri."[http://web.archive.org/web/20090604080723/http://www.jetairways.com/EN/US/ContactUs/ContactUsRegisteredOffice.aspx Registered Office]." Jet Airways. Retrieved on 27 February 2010. "Jet Airways (India) Ltd. S.M. Centre, Andheri-Kurla Road, Andheri (East), Mumbai 400059 India"Meredith, Robyn. "[http://www.forbes.com/global/2008/0407/016.html Beyond Airlines,Beyond India]." ''[[Forbes]]''. 20 March 2008. Magazine dated 7 April 2008. Retrieved on 27 February 2010. In 2008 Robyn Meredith of ''[[Forbes]]'' stated that the complex was "as shabby as (Jet Airways CEO Nares) Goyal's home is posh" and that the complex was "In need of a fresh coat of paint". The complex was 15 minutes driving time from [[Chhatrapati Shivaji International Airport]]. ===Subsidiaries=== ====JetLite==== ''[[JetLite]]'' is a wholly owned subsidiary of Jet Airways. It was established as Sahara Airlines on 20 September 1991 and began operations on 3 December 1993 with two [[Boeing 737|Boeing 737-200]] aircraft. Initially services were primarily concentrated in the northern sectors of India, keeping Delhi as its base, and then operations were extended to cover all the country. Sahara Airlines was rebranded as Air Sahara on 2 October 2000. On 12 April 2007 Jet Airways took over Air Sahara and on 16 April 2007 Air Sahara was renamed as JetLite. JetLite operates a fleet of mixed ownedâleased [[Boeing 737 Next Generation]] aircraft and [[Bombardier CRJ-200]]ER. ====Jet Konnect==== '''Jet Konnect''' is the low-cost brand of [[India]]-based Jet Airways. It was launched on 8 May 2009, and shares the same airline designation as Jet Airways.{{cite web|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/jet-airways-launches-lowcost-service-jet-konnect/92012-7.html|title=Jet Airways launches low-cost service Jet Konnect|publisher=IBNLive.com|accessdate=}} It operates a mixed fleet of [[ATR 72-500]]s and [[Boeing 737 Next Generation|Boeing 737-800]]s. The rationale for launching Jet Airways Konnect was to close down loss-making routes and divert the planes to more profitable routes with higher [[passenger load factor]]s. Jet already runs a low-cost airline named [[JetLite]]. According to Jet Airways, the decision to launch a low-cost brand instead of expanding the existing [[low-cost airline|JetLite]] was taken to avoid the regulatory delays associated with moving excess aircraft and assets from Jet Airways to JetLite, which have separate operating codes. Jet Konnect offers a no frills flight where meals and other refreshments have to be purchased on board. To identify if the flight is a full service or Konnect the flight numbers for Konnect are in the series 9W 2000-2999.{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/2009/05/08/stories/2009050851921500.htm|title=Jet Airwaysâ low-fare service Konnect takes off today|publisher=The Hindu Business Line|accessdate=}} Jet Airways plan to merge JetLite brand into Jet Konnect in the future. ==Destinations== {{Main|Jet Airways destinations}} Jet Airways serves 52 domestic destinations and 24 international destinations, a total of 76{{cite web|title=Our Network|publisher=Jet Airways|url=http://www.jetairways.com/EN/AU/AboutUs/OurNetwork.aspx|accessdate=9 December 2010}} in 19 countries across southern [[Africa]], [[Asia]], [[Europe]] and [[North America]]. Short-haul destinations are served using [[Boeing 737 Next Generation]]. [[ATR 72-500]]s are used only on domestic regional routes, while long-haul routes are served using its [[Airbus A330#A330-200|Airbus A330-200]] and [[Boeing 777#777-300ER|Boeing 777-300ER]] aircraft. [[London]], [[England]] was the airline's first long-haul destination and was launched in 2005. Since 2007 Jet Airways has had a scissors hub at [[Brussels Airport]] in [[Belgium]] for onward [[Transatlantic flight|trans-atlantic]] connections to [[Canada]] and the [[United States]]. ===Codeshare agreements=== Jet Airways has [[codeshare agreement]]s with the following airlines:[http://www.jetairways.com/EN/IN/AboutUs/CodeShare.aspx Codeshare Partners] {| |- valign="top" | * [[Air Canada]] ([[Star Alliance]]) * [[Alitalia]] ([[SkyTeam]]) * [[All Nippon Airways]] ([[Star Alliance]]) * [[American Airlines]] ([[Oneworld]]) | * [[Brussels Airlines]] ([[Star Alliance]]) * [[Etihad Airways]] * [[Gulf Air]] * [[JetLite]] (subsidiary) | * [[Kenya Airways]] ([[SkyTeam]]) * [[Malaysia Airlines]] (future [[Oneworld]] member) * [[Qantas]] ([[Oneworld]]) * [[United Airlines]] ([[Star Alliance]]) |} Jet Airways also has a codesharing agreement with [[Thalys]] European rail service.[http://in.news.yahoo.com/jet-airways-forms-air-rail-code-share-thalys-124248337.html Jet Airways forms air-rail code share with Thalys - Yahoo!] ==Fleet== [[File:Jetairways a330-200 vt-jwf arp.jpg|thumb|[[Airbus A330#A330-200|Airbus A330-200]] landing at [[Birmingham International Airport, West Midlands|Birmingham International Airport]].]] [[File:Jet Airways ATR.jpg|thumb|[[ATR 72#ATR 72â500|ATR 72-500]]]] [[File:Jet Airways .jpg|thumb|[[Boeing 737 Next Generation|Boeing 737-700]] taking off from [[Boeing Field]]]] [[File:Jet Airways San Francisco.jpg|thumb|Jet Airways [[Boeing 777#777-300ER|Boeing 777-300ER]] at [[San Francisco International Airport]].]] The [[List of Boeing customer codes|Boeing customer code]] for Jet Airways is 5R. The airline is known for constantly maintaining its average fleet age below 10 years with regular phasing out of aircraft which are over 10 years of age.{{Citation needed|date=June 2011}} As of May 2011, the Jet Airways fleet consists of the following aircraft with an average age of 5.4 years:[http://www.jetairways.com/Cultures/en-US/India/About+Us/Our+Fleet/ jetairways.com â Fleet Information] accessdate 20 March 2010[http://www.airbus.com/fileadmin/backstage/documents/od/February_2010.xls Airbus â Orders, Deliveries, Operators] Summary to 28th Feb 2010[http://active.boeing.com/commercial/orders/index.cfm?content=customerselection.cfm&pageid=m15524 Boeing â Orders and deliveries] Customer Summary Through February 2010[http://www.planespotters.net/Airline/Jet-Airways Jet Airways fleet list at planespotters.net]

===Retired=== Jet Airways previously operated the following aircraft:

[[Boeing 777#777-300ER|Boeing 777-300ER]] |All were dry leased. |- |[[Boeing 737 Classic|Boeing 737-300]] |align=center|4 |1993â1999 |rowspan=3|[[Boeing 737 Next Generation]] |All were dry leased. |- |[[Boeing 737 Classic|Boeing 737-400]] |align=center|16 |1995â2010 |12 were dry leased. |- |[[Boeing 737 Classic|Boeing 737-500]] |align=center|5 |1996â2001 |All were dry leased. |- |'''Total''' |align=center|'''28''' |colspan=3| |}
===Livery=== ;1993â2007 [[File:Jet.airways.a340.london.arp.jpg|thumb|Jet Airways [[Airbus A340|Airbus A340-300]] at [[London Heathrow Airport]] in 2005 with the 1993-2007 livery]] [[File:Jet Airways India.jpg|thumb|Jet Airways [[Boeing 777#777-300ER|Boeing 777-300ER]] with the present livery]] Jet Airways' original livery was [[Navy Blue]], [[Light Grey]] and [[Chrome Yellow]]. The top and bottom of the aircraft were painted in light grey and had the flying sun logo in the navy blue background. ;2007âpresent Jet Airways' current livery was introduced in 2007.{{cite web|url=http://www.business-standard.com/india/news/jet-airways-sports-new-look/14/21/281436/|title=Jet Airways sports new look|publisher=Business Standard|date=04-2007|accessdate=2009-03-03}} The design retained the dark blue and gold-accented colour scheme of Jet Airways' previous corporate identity, along with the airline's "flying sun" logo. The new livery, created with [[Landor Associates]], added yellow and gold ribbons. A new yellow uniform was simultaneously introduced, created by [[Italians|Italian]] designer [[Roberto Capucci]]. Jet Airways introduced its new identity in conjunction with a global brand re-launch which included new aircraft and seating. ==Services== ===Cabin=== ====Domestic & international short haul==== [[Boeing 737 Next Generation]] aircraft are configured in and Economy Classes. Some Boeing 737s have an all Economy Class cabin layout. The [[ATR 72-500]] have Economy class configuration only. ;PremiÃ¨re The PremiÃ¨re features 40-inch extra-wide seats with a personal Widescreen LCD attached to each seat. The PremiÃ¨re cabin is configured in a 2-2 abreast pattern. ;Economy Class Jet Airways Economy class on its [[Boeing 737 Next Generation]] features 30-inch seat pitch with personal Widescreen LCD behind each seat. Jet Airways was the World's first airline to introduce in-flight entertainment systems on the [[Boeing 737]] aircraft. The Economy class cabin is configured in a 3-3 abreast pattern on the Boeing 737 Next Generation and 2-2 abreast pattern on the ATR 72-500.{{cn|date=November 2011}} ====International long haul==== [[File:Jet Airways 777 First Class cabin.jpg|thumb|''First Class'' on board the Boeing 777-300ER]] With the arrival of its new [[Airbus A330#A330-200|Airbus A330-200]] and [[Boeing 777#777-300ER|Boeing 777-300ER]] aircraft, Jet Airways has introduced a new cabin with upgraded seats in all classes. The Airbus A330-200 aircraft have two classes: PremiÃ¨re and Economy. The Boeing 777-300ER aircraft has three classes of service: First, PremiÃ¨re (Business), and Economy. Jet Airways has a three-star rated First and Business Class, and is in the top twenty-five business classes reviewed by [[Skytrax]]. Economy class has been reviewed as a three-star product by [[Skytrax]]. Being a Full Service Airline, meals are served on all classes of travel. ;First Class First class is available on all Boeing 777-300ER aircraft. All seats convert to a fully flat bed, similar to Singapore Airlines first class seat but much smaller. It was the twenty-second airline in the world to have private suites. All seats in First have a 23-inch widescreen LCD monitor with audio-video on-demand systems (AVOD), [[BOSE]] noise cancelling headphones, in seat power supply, and [[USB]] ports etc. Jet Airways is the first Indian airline to offer fully enclosed suites on its aircraft; each suite has a closable door, making for a private compartment. [[Skytrax]] consumer airline reviewers recently rated Jet Airways First Class as being 14th best in the world. ;PremiÃ¨re [[File:Jet Airways 777 Premiere cabin.jpg|thumb|''PremiÃ¨re'' on board the Boeing 777-300ER]] PremiÃ¨re (Business Class) on the Airbus A330-200 and Boeing 777-300ER international fleet has a fully flat bed with AVOD entertainment. Seats are configured in a [[Herringbone seating|herringbone]] pattern (1-2-1 on the Boeing 777-300ER, and 1-1-1 on the Airbus A330-200), with each seat offering direct access to the aisle. PremiÃ¨re seats on the A330-200s leased from [[ILFC]] are configured differently in a 2-2-2 non-[[Herringbone seating|herringbone]] pattern. Each PremiÃ¨re Seat has a 15.4-inch flat screen LCD TV with AVOD. USB ports and in-seat laptop power are provided. All seats are standard recliner business-class seats with a few newer aircraft with electronic recline and massager. ;Economy Class Economy class on Jet's A330-200/777-300ER aircraft has 32-inch seat pitch. Seats on the A330-200/777-300ER have a "hammock-style" net footrest. The cabin is configured in 2-4-2 abreast on the Airbus A330-200, 3-3-3 on the Boeing 777-300ER. Each Economy seat on the A330-200/777-300ER has a personal 10.6-inch touch screen LCD TV with AVOD.

All three classes feature Mood lighting on the Airbus A330-200 and Boeing 777-300ER, with light schemes corresponding to the time of day and flight position. [[File:Jet Airways JetScreen IFE.jpg|thumb|JetScreen IFE in Economy class on-board a [[Boeing 737 Next Generation|Boeing 737-800]]]] ====In-flight entertainment==== Jet Airways' ''[[Panasonic Avionics Corporation|Panasonic eFX]]'' IFE system on-board the [[Boeing 737 Next Generation|Boeing 737-700/800]] and ''[[Panasonic Avionics Corporation|Panasonic eX2]]'' IFE system on-board the [[Airbus A330#A330-200|Airbus A330-200]]/[[Boeing 777#777-300ER|Boeing 777-300ER]], called "JetScreen", offers audio video on-demand programming (passengers can start, stop, rewind, and fast-forward as desired). It has over 100 movies, 80 TV programmes, 11 audio channels and a CD library of 125 titles. The system operates via individual [[touchscreen]] monitors at each seat, and is available in all classes.{{cite web|url=http://www.nationmultimedia.com/2007/07/21/travel/travel_30041711.php|title=Finally, incredible India|publisher=The Nation|accessdate=2009-03-03|last=Verghese |first=Vijay|date=2007-7}} ===Airport lounges=== Jet Airways Lounges are offered to First and PremiÃ¨re Class passengers, along with JetPrivilege Platinum, Gold or Silver card members. The international lounge at Brussels has showers, business centre, entertainment facilities and children's play areas.{{cite web|url=http://www.business-standard.com/india/storypage.php?tp=on&autono=29346|title=Jet opens lounge at Brussels airport|publisher=Business Standard|accessdate=2009-03-03|date=2007-10}} Lounges are located in: [[Bangalore]], [[Brussels]], [[Chennai]], [[Cochin]], [[Delhi]], [[Hyderabad, India|Hyderabad]], [[Jaipur]], [[Kolkata]], [[Mumbai]], [[Newark, New Jersey|Newark]] ===Frequent-flyer program=== JetPrivilege is Jet Airwaysâ [[frequent-flyer program]]. ===Ban on Meat Products=== In June 2011, Jet Airways banned carrying fish, crab, meat and poultry products as check-in baggage.[http://www.hindustantimes.com/India-news/Mumbai/Jet-Airways-bans-meat-products-fliers-upset/Article1-762303.aspx Jet Airways bans meat products, fliers upset - Hindustan Times] Jet is the first domestic airline to impose such a ban. Jet claimed that passengers complained of their baggage getting soiled by seepage from bags containing meat products. ==Awards and achievements== Jet Airways has been given a 3-star rating by [[Skytrax]]. * ''Best First-Class Service in the World'' award at Business Travellerâs 20th annual âBest in Business Travelâ awards * ''Best Business Class & Best Economy Class'' at the Business Traveller Awards * ''Best Program of the Year'' by Freddie Awards 2007 & 2006 * ''Best Elite Level'' for the second year in a row, at the 21st Annual presentation ceremony of the Freddie Awards 2008 * ''Best Overall in Entertainment'' at the Avion Awards 2010 * ''India's Popular Domestic Airline'' at the SATTE 2006 Awards * ''Indiaâs Airline'' at the World Travel Awards, 2006 * ''Best Technical Despatch Reliability'' by Beaver 2002 * ''Best Cargo Airline of North Asia'' by Cargo Airline of the Year Awards * ''Best Domestic Airline'' award for the 1st consecutive year and the 5th time in the past two years at the 18th TTG (Travel Trade Gazette) Travel Awards 2007 * ''Service Excellence Award'' at Global Managers in Jurassic Park, Sudan. * ''Indiaâs Most Respected Company in the Travel and Food Sector'' by Businessworld 2003 * ''Best Long Haul Carrier'' ex-Brussels award at the Tm Travel Awards 2009. * ''Best Eastbound Airline from India'' and ''Best domestic Airline in India'' awards at the Abacus Tafi Awards 2009. * Business Travellerâs ''Best Indian Airline'' Award In London. :According to.[http://www.jetairways.com/Cultures/en-US/United+States+of+America/About+Us/Awards/?UserPref=culture^en-US Awards] ==Incidents and accidents== * On 1 July 2007, Jet Airways Flight 3307, a [[ATR 72|ATR 72-212A]] (registered VT-JCE) which was flying on the [[Bhopal]]-[[Indore]] route was involved in an accident which was caused by a storm. There were no fatalities amongst the 45 passengers and 4 crew onboard, however the aircraft suffered damages beyond repair.{{ASN|20070701-0}} ==See also== {{Portal box|India|Mumbai|Companies|Aviation}} *[[Naresh Goyal]] *[[JetLite]] *[[List of airlines of India]] *[[List of airports in India]] *[[List of companies of India]] *[[Transport in India]] {{-}} == References == {{Reflist|2}} {{Commons category|Jet Konnect}} {{Portal box|Mumbai|Companies|Aviation}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Jet Airways}} * {{Official website|http://www.jetairways.com}} *[http://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=10000080&sid=aoiJyQLQtPOE Indian Aviation Business] news report on [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] *[http://www.nerve.in/timeline:jet+airways News timeline for Jet Airways] *[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/south_asia/6547941.stm/ Jet Airways buyout of Air Sahara on BBC news]{{dead link|date=January 2011}} *[http://www.southalltravel.co.uk/Airline/Jet-Airways/ Jet Airways Guide] * [http://www.jetairways.com/EN/GL/ProductAndServices/JetAirwaysKonnect.aspx Jet Konnect page at Jet Airways website] {{Airlines of India}} {{IATA members|asia}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2010}} [[Category:Airlines of India]] [[Category:IATA members]] [[Category:Airlines established in 1992]] [[Category:Companies based in Mumbai]] [[Category:Companies listed on the National Stock Exchange of India]] [[da:Jet Airways]] [[de:Jet Airways]] [[es:Jet Airways]] [[fr:Jet Airways (Inde)]] [[hi:à¤à¥à¤ à¤à¤¯à¤°à¤µà¥à¤]] [[id:Jet Airways]] [[it:Jet Airways]] [[he:×'× ××××¨×××××]] [[kn:à²à³à²à³â à²à²°à³à²µà³à²¸à³]] [[hu:Jet Airways]] [[mr:à¤à¥à¤ à¤à¤à¤°à¤µà¥à¤]] [[nl:Jet Airways]] [[ja:ã¸ã§ããã¨ã¢ã¦ã§ã¤ãº]] [[no:Jet Airways (India) Ltd]] [[pl:Jet Airways]] [[pt:Jet Airways]] [[ru:Jet Airways]] [[fi:Jet Airways]] [[sv:Jet Airways]] [[ta:à®à¯à®à¯ à®à®°à¯à®µà¯à®¸à¯]] [[vi:Jet Airways]] [[zh:æ·ç¹èªç©º]]
